translated_dialog: This is the time that Madam Silvia told me to come and talk to her. There's something she wants me to do. [To SILVIA] Madam, madam!
og_response: Who calls?

translated_dialog: Who's calling me?
og_response: Your servant and your friend;One that attends your ladyship's command.

translated_dialog: Your servant and your friend. One that is waiting to hear your Ladyship's order.
og_response: Sir Eglamour, a thousand times good morrow.

translated_dialog: Sir Eglamour, a thousand times good morning.
og_response: As many, worthy lady, to yourself:    According to your ladyship's impose,    I am thus early come to know what service    It is your pleasure to command me in.

translated_dialog: As many good mornings to yourself, worthy lady. According to your ladyship's command, I was supposed to come this early to find out what service you'd like me to carry out.
og_response: O Eglamour, thou art a gentleman    Think not I flatter, for I swear I do not    Valiant, wise, remorseful, well accomplish'd:    Thou art not ignorant what dear good will    I bear unto the banish'd Valentine,    Nor how my father would enforce me marry    Vain Turio, whom my very soul abhors.    Thyself hast loved; and I have heard thee say    No grief did ever come so near thy heart    As when thy lady and thy true love died,    Upon whose grave thou vow'dst pure chastity.    Sir Eglamour, I would to Valentine,    To Mantua, where I hear he makes abode;    And, for the ways are dangerous to pass,    I do desire thy worthy company,    Upon whose faith and honour I repose.    Urge not my father's anger, Eglamour,    But think upon my grief, a lady's grief,    And on the justice of my flying hence,    To keep me from a most unholy match,    Which heaven and fortune still rewards with plagues.    I do desire thee, even from a heart    As full of sorrows as the sea of sands,    To bear me company and go with me:    If not, to hide what I have said to thee,    That I may venture to depart alone.

translated_dialog: Oh, Eglamour, you are a gentleman. Don't think that I'm flattering you; I swear I'm not. You are brave, wise, compassionate, well-accomplished. You know how much I care about the banished Valentine, and how my father wants to force me to marry the foolish Turio, whom I hate with all my heart. You have been in love. And I have heard you say that you have never felt more grief in your heart than you did when your ladyyour true lovedied. And you have vowed pure chastity on her grave. Sir Eglamour, I want to go to Valentine in Mantua, where I heard he is. And since the journey is dangerous, I would like your worthy company, because I rely on your faith and honor. Don't encourage my father's anger, Eglamour. Just think about my griefa lady's griefand about the justice of my running away from here; and from a most unholy marriagewhich heaven and fortune would always make horrible. This is coming from a heart as full of sorrows as the sea is full of sand. I want you to keep me company and go with me. If you won't then keep secret what I have said to you so that I may go alone.
og_response: Madam, I pity much your grievances;    Which since I know they virtuously are placed,    I give consent to go along with you,    Recking as little what betideth me    As much I wish all good befortune you.    When will you go?

translated_dialog: Madam, I am sorry for your distress. Since I know your cause is right and virtuous, I agree to go with you. I don't care much about what will happen to me. My wish is that only good things happen to you. When are you planning on going?
og_response: This evening coming.

translated_dialog: This evening.
og_response: Where shall I meet you?

translated_dialog: Where shall I meet you?
og_response: At Friar Patrick's cell,Where I intend holy confession.

translated_dialog: At Friar Patrick's cell, where I intend to make a holy confession.
og_response: I will not fail your ladyship. Good morrow, gentle lady.

translated_dialog: You can rely on me, your Ladyship. Have a good morning, gentle lady.
og_response: Good morrow, kind Sir Eglamour.

translated_dialog: When a master's servant behaves like a dog to him, it is tough. I brought this one up from a puppy; I saved this one from drowning, when three or four of his blind brothers and sisters drowned. I have taught him, even as one would say precisely, "I would teach a dog like this." I was sent to deliver him as a present from my master to Mistress Silvia, and as soon as I came into the dining room, he comes to her plate and steals her chicken leg. Oh, it's a horrible thing when a dog can't behave himself in different kinds of company! But, as they really should say, I happen to have a dog that is a dog indeeda dog in everything he does. If I didn't have more wisdom than he doesto plead guilty for his wrongdoingI really think he would have been hanged for it. For as sure as I live, he's suffered for it, as you'll see. He thrusts me himself into the company of three or four gentlemanly dogs under the Duke's table. He had not been there (pardon my language) as long as the time it takes to pissand everybody in the room smelled him. "Out with the dog!" someone says. "What dog is that?" someone else says. "Whip him!" a third says. "Hang him up" says the Duke. Since I have known the smell before, I knew it was Crab. So I go to the man that whips the dogs: "Friend," I say, "are you going to whip the dog?" "Yes, I am" he says. "You'll make things even worse for him if you do," I say. "I was the one who did the thing you know about." He makes no more fuss about it, but whips me out of the room. How many masters would do this for their servants? No, I swear, I have sat in the stocks for sausages he has stolen. Otherwise, he would have been executed. I have also been punished for geese he has killed. Otherwise, he would have suffered for it. Don't think about this now. No, I remember the trick you played on me when I left Madam Silvia. Didn't I ask you to always pay attention to me, just like I pay attention to you? When did you see me raise up my leg and urinate onto a gentlewoman's skirt? Have you ever seen me do such a trick?
og_response: Sebastian is thy name? I like thee wellAnd will employ thee in some service presently.

translated_dialog: [To JULIA] Is your name Sebastian? I like you, and so I'll give you a job to do soon.
og_response: In what you please: I'll do what I can.

translated_dialog: I'll do whatever you'd like, if I can.
og_response: I hope thou wilt.

translated_dialog: I hope you will.
og_response: [to LANCE]  How now, you whoreson peasant!Where have you been these two days loitering?

translated_dialog: [To LANCE] What's this? You bastard peasant! Where have you been these past two days?
og_response: Marry, sir, I carried Mistress Silvia the dog you bade me.

translated_dialog: I carried the dog to Mistress Silvia like you asked me to, sir.
og_response: And what says she to my little jewel?

translated_dialog: And what does she say to my pretty little dog?
og_response: Marry, she says your dog was a cur, and tells youcurrish thanks is good enough for such a present.

translated_dialog: She says that your dog is badly-behaved. And she tells you that a snide "thanks" is good enough for a present like that.
og_response: But she received my dog?

translated_dialog: But did she receive my dog?
og_response: No, indeed, did she not: here have I brought himback again.

translated_dialog: No, she didn't. I have brought him back here again.
og_response: What, didst thou offer her this from me?

translated_dialog: Wait a second! Did you offer her this dog from me?
og_response: Ay, sir: the other squirrel was stolen from me by    the hangman boys in the market-place:   and then I    offered her mine own, who is a dog as big as ten of    yours,   and therefore the gift the greater.

translated_dialog: Yes, sir. Some mischievous boys in the market square stole the other small dog from me. So then I offered her my own dog, who is as big as ten of yours. And therefore the gift was all the greater.
og_response: Go get thee hence, and find my dog again,    Or ne'er return again into my sight.    Away, I say! Stay'st thou to vex me here?

translated_dialog: Get out of here and go find my dog! And if you don't, I don't ever want to see you again. Go away, I say! Are you staying here to make me angry?
og_response: A slave, that still an end turns me to shame!    Sebastian, I have entertained thee,    Partly that I have need of such a youth    That can with some discretion do my business,    For 'tis no trusting to yond foolish lout,    But chiefly for thy face and thy behavior,    Which, if my augury deceive me not,    Witness good bringing up, fortune and truth:    Therefore know thou, for this I entertain thee.    Go presently and take this ring with thee,    Deliver it to Madam Silvia:    She loved me well deliver'd it to me.

translated_dialog: He is a rascal that continuously makes me ashamed! Sebastian, I have taken you into service, partly because I need such a young boy who can carry out my business with discretion. There's no point in trusting that foolish man over there. But I have mostly employed you because of your face and your manners, whichif my prediction is correctare evidence of a good upbringing, fortune, and truth. Therefore, you should know that I have taken you for these reasons. Go at once and take this ring with you. Deliver it to Madam Silvia. The girl who gave it to me loved me well.
og_response: It seems you loved not her, to leave her token.She is dead, belike?

translated_dialog: It seems that you didn't love her, since you parted with her token. Is she dead?
og_response: Not so; I think she lives.

translated_dialog: No, I think she is alive.
og_response: Alas!

translated_dialog: Ah!
og_response: Why dost thou cry 'alas'?

translated_dialog: Why do you cry, "Ah?"
og_response: I cannot chooseBut pity her.

translated_dialog: I can't help myself: I feel sorry for her.
og_response: Wherefore shouldst thou pity her?

translated_dialog: Why should you feel sorry for her?
og_response: Because methinks that she loved you as well    As you do love your lady Silvia:    She dreams of him that has forgot her love;    You dote on her that cares not for your love.    'Tis pity love should be so contrary;    And thinking of it makes me cry 'alas!'

translated_dialog: Because I think that she loved you as well as you love your lady Silvia. She dreams of the man who has forgotten her love. You are obsessed with someone who doesn't care to have your love. It's a pity that love should be so contrary. And thinking of it makes me cry, "Ah!"
og_response: Well, give her that ring and therewithal    This letter. That's her chamber.   Tell my lady    I claim the promise for her heavenly picture.    Your message done, hie home unto my chamber,    Where thou shalt find me, sad and solitary.

translated_dialog: Well, give her that ring, and with it, this letter. That's her room there. Tell my lady that she should keep her promise and give me her heavenly picture. Once you deliver the message, go home to my room, where you will find me sad and alone.
og_response: How many women would do such a message?    Alas, poor Proteus! Thou hast entertain'd    A fox to be the shepherd of thy lambs.    Alas, poor fool! Why do I pity him    That with his very heart despiseth me?    Because he loves her, he despiseth me;    Because I love him I must pity him.    This ring I gave him when he parted from me,    To bind him to remember my good will;    And now am I, unhappy messenger,    To plead for that which I would not obtain,    To carry that which I would have refused,    To praise his faith which I would have dispraised.    I am my master's true-confirmed love;    But cannot be true servant to my master,    Unless I prove false traitor to myself.    Yet will I woo for him, but yet so coldly    As, heaven it knows, I would not have him speed.

translated_dialog: How many women would carry such a message? Ah, poor Proteus! You have employed a fox to be the shepherd of your lambs. Oh, I am a poor fool! Why do I pity the man who hates me with his heart? Because he loves her, he hates me.  And because I love him, I have to feel sorry for him. I gave him this ring when we said goodbyeto make him promise to remember me. And now I am an unhappy messenger, who has to ask for the picture that I don't want to get; to carry the ring which I should have refused; to praise his faithwhich I should have said bad things about. I am my master's truly-confirmed love. But I cannot be a true servant to my master, unless I betray myself. Yes, I will woo Silvia for him. But I'll do it coldly since I don't want him to succeed, as heaven knows.
og_response: Gentlewoman, good day! I pray you, be my meanTo bring me where to speak with Madam Silvia.

translated_dialog: Good day, gentlewoman! I beg you to take me where I can speak with Madam Silvia.
og_response: What would you with her, if that I be she?

translated_dialog: What do you want with her? Pretend that I'm her.
og_response: If you be she, I do entreat your patienceTo hear me speak the message I am sent on.

translated_dialog: If you are her, then I ask you to patiently hear the message I am sent here to deliver.
og_response: From whom?

translated_dialog: A message from whom?
og_response: From my master, Sir Proteus, madam.

translated_dialog: From my master, Sir Proteus, madam.
og_response: O, he sends you for a picture.

translated_dialog: Oh, he sends you here for a picture.
og_response: Ay, madam.

translated_dialog: Yes, madam.
og_response: Ursula, bring my picture here.    Go give your master this:   tell him from me,    One Julia, that his changing thoughts forget,    Would better fit his chamber than this shadow.

translated_dialog: [To a servant] Ursula, bring my picture here. [To JULIA] Go and give your master this. Tell him, from me, that one Juliawhom he has forgotten in his changing thoughtswould better suit his room than this shadow of a picture.
og_response: Madam, please you peruse this letter.    Pardon me, madam;   I have unadvised    Deliver'd you a paper that I should not:    This is the letter to your ladyship.

translated_dialog: [She hands SILVIA a letter] Madam, please read this letterWait! Pardon me, madam. I have accidentally given you a paper that I shouldn't have. [She hands SILVIA another letter] This is the letter addressed to your Ladyship.
og_response: I pray thee, let me look on that again.

translated_dialog: Please, let me look at that one again.
og_response: It may not be; good madam, pardon me.

translated_dialog: No, I don't think that's a good idea, good madam. Forgive me.
og_response: There, hold!    I will not look upon your master's lines:    I know they are stuff'd with protestations    And full of new-found oaths; which he will break    As easily as I do tear his paper.

translated_dialog: Wait a moment! I will not read your master's lines. I know they are full of declarations of love and recently-invented oathswhich he will break as easily as I tear his letter apart.
og_response: Madam, he sends your ladyship this ring.

translated_dialog: Madam, he sends your Ladyship this ring.
og_response: The more shame for him that he sends it me;    For I have heard him say a thousand times    His Julia gave it him at his departure.    Though his false finger have profaned the ring,    Mine shall not do his Julia so much wrong.

translated_dialog: He should be ashamed for sending it to me, because I have heard him say a thousand times that his Julia gave him this ring when they said goodbye. Though his false finger has abused the ring, my finger will not do his Julia so much wrong by wearing the ring.
og_response: She thanks you.

translated_dialog: She thanks you.
og_response: What say'st thou?

translated_dialog: What did you say?
og_response: I thank you, madam, that you tender her.Poor gentlewoman! My master wrongs her much.

translated_dialog: I thank you, madam, that you care for her. Poor gentlewoman! My master has really wronged her.
og_response: Dost thou know her?

translated_dialog: Do you know her?
og_response: Almost as well as I do know myself:To think upon her woes I do protestThat I have wept a hundred several times.

translated_dialog: Almost as well as I know myself. I have thought about her suffering a hundred times, and it has made me cry.
og_response: Belike she thinks that Proteus hath forsook her.

translated_dialog: She probably thinks that Proteus has abandoned her.
og_response: I think she doth; and that's her cause of sorrow.

translated_dialog: I think she does, and that's why she is mourning.
og_response: Is she not passing fair?

translated_dialog: Isn't she beautiful?
og_response: She hath been fairer, madam, than she is:    When she did think my master loved her well,    She, in my judgment, was as fair as you:    But since she did neglect her looking-glass    And threw her sun-expelling mask away,    The air hath starved the roses in her cheeks    And pinch'd the lily-tincture of her face,    That now she is become as black as I.

translated_dialog: She has been more beautiful than she is now, madam. When she thought that my master loved her, I think she was as beautiful as you. But since she stopped looking in the mirror and threw her mask away, the air has starved the rosy blush on her cheeks, and eroded the lily-white color of her face, so now she has become as black as I.
og_response: How tall was she?

translated_dialog: How tall was she?
og_response: About my stature; for at Pentecost,    When all our pageants of delight were play'd,    Our youth got me to play the woman's part,    And I was trimm'd in Madam Julia's gown,    Which served me as fit, by all men's judgments,    As if the garment had been made for me:    Therefore I know she is about my height.    And at that time I made her weep agood,    For I did play a lamentable part:    Madam, 'twas Ariadne passioning    For Theseus' perjury and unjust flight;    Which I so lively acted with my tears    That my poor mistress, moved therewithal,    Wept bitterly; and would I might be dead    If I in thought felt not her very sorrow!

translated_dialog: About my height, because at Pentecost, when all our enjoyable plays are performed, I played the woman's part. And I dressed up in Madam Julia's dress, which fitted me as well as my men's clothes, as if the dress was made for me. Therefore, I know she is about my height. And, at that time, I made her cry in earnest because I played a tragic role. It was Ariadne's passionate sorrowing for Theseus not keeping his promise and unjustly running away, madam. I was so convincing with my acting, and even shed tears. Because of this, my poor mistressmoved by it allcried bitterly. If I didn't feel her sorrow in that moment, I should have been dead!
og_response: She is beholding to thee, gentle youth.    Alas, poor lady, desolate and left!    I weep myself to think upon thy words.    Here, youth, there is my purse; I give thee this    For thy sweet mistress' sake, because thou lovest her.    Farewell.

translated_dialog: She is indebted to you, gentle boy. Ah, poor lady, abandoned and left behind! I cry just thinking about your words. Here, boy, take my purse. I give you this for the sake of your sweet mistress, because you love her. Goodbye.
og_response: And she shall thank you for't, if e'er you know her.    A virtuous gentlewoman, mild and beautiful    I hope my master's suit will be but cold,    Since she respects my mistress' love so much.    Alas, how love can trifle with itself!    Here is her picture: let me see; I think,    If I had such a tire, this face of mine    Were full as lovely as is this of hers:    And yet the painter flatter'd her a little,    Unless I flatter with myself too much.    Her hair is auburn, mine is perfect yellow:    If that be all the difference in his love,    I'll get me such a colour'd periwig.    Her eyes are grey as glass, and so are mine:    Ay, but her forehead's low, and mine's as high.    What should it be that he respects in her    But I can make respective in myself,    If this fond Love were not a blinded god?    Come, shadow, come and take this shadow up,    For 'tis thy rival. O thou senseless form,    Thou shalt be worshipp'd, kiss'd, loved and adored!    And, were there sense in his idolatry,    My substance should be statue in thy stead.    I'll use thee kindly for thy mistress' sake,    That used me so; or else, by Jove I vow,    I should have scratch'd out your unseeing eyes    To make my master out of love with thee!

translated_dialog: The sun begins to tinge the western sky with gold. And now it's time for Silva to meet me at Friar Patrick's place. She won't be late. Lovers never miss the time they're supposed to meet upunless they arrive early if they really can't wait to see each other. Here she comes.
og_response: Lady, a happy evening!

translated_dialog: Good evening to you, lady!
og_response: Amen, amen! Go on, good Eglamour,Out at the postern by the abbey-wall:I fear I am attended by some spies.

translated_dialog: Amen to that! Let's go, good Eglamour. Let's go out at the back gate by the abbey wall. I am afraid that some spies are following me.
og_response: Fear not: the forest is not three leagues off;If we recover that, we are sure enough.

translated_dialog: Sir Proteus, what does Silvia say about my wooing?
og_response: O, sir, I find her milder than she was;And yet she takes exceptions at your person.

translated_dialog: Oh, sir, I think she is more gracious than she was before. And yet, she is not so sure about your physical appearance.
og_response: What, that my leg is too long?

translated_dialog: What? Is it because my legs are too long?
og_response: No; that it is too little.

translated_dialog: No, it's because your legs are too thin.
og_response: I'll wear a boot, to make it somewhat rounder.

translated_dialog: I'll wear boots to make my legs look a bit thicker.
og_response: [Aside]  But love will not be spurr'd to whatit loathes.

translated_dialog: [To herself] But love won't be inspired by something it hates.
og_response: What says she to my face?

translated_dialog: What does she say about my face?
og_response: She says it is a fair one.

translated_dialog: She says it's pale.
og_response: Nay then, the wanton lies; my face is black.

translated_dialog: No, I think that willful woman lies. My face is tan.
og_response: But pearls are fair; and the old saying is,Black men are pearls in beauteous ladies' eyes.

translated_dialog: But pearls are white. And the old saying goes that tan men are pearls in the eyes of beautiful ladies.
og_response: [Aside]  'Tis true; such pearls as put outladies' eyes;For I had rather wink than look on them.

translated_dialog: [To herself] That's true. Such pearls make ladies' eyes useless. I would rather shut my eyes than look at them.
og_response: How likes she my discourse?

translated_dialog: How does she like my conversation?
og_response: Ill, when you talk of war.

translated_dialog: She doesn't like it when you talk about violence.
og_response: But well, when I discourse of love and peace?

translated_dialog: Then, what does she think when I speak about love and peace?
og_response: [Aside]  But better, indeed, when you hold your peace.

translated_dialog: [To herself] It's better when you just keep silent.
og_response: What says she to my valour?

translated_dialog: What does she say about my bravery?
og_response: O, sir, she makes no doubt of that.

translated_dialog: Oh, sir, she has no doubt of that.
og_response: [Aside]  She needs not, when she knows it cowardice.

translated_dialog: [To herself] She doesn't need to doubt your bravery, because she knows that you're a coward.
og_response: What says she to my birth?

translated_dialog: What does she say about my noble ancestry?
og_response: That you are well derived.

translated_dialog: That you are well descended.
og_response: [Aside]  True; from a gentleman to a fool.

translated_dialog: [To herself] True. You've gone from a gentleman to a fool.
og_response: Considers she my possessions?

translated_dialog: Does she consider my possessions?
og_response: O, ay; and pities them.

translated_dialog: Oh, yes, and she feels sorry for them.
og_response: Wherefore?

translated_dialog: Why?
og_response: [Aside]  That such an ass should owe them.

translated_dialog: [To herself] Because such an ass owns them.
og_response: That they are out by lease.

translated_dialog: That they are borrowed or rented and not entirely in your possession.
og_response: Here comes the duke.

translated_dialog: Here comes the Duke.
og_response: How now, Sir Proteus! How now, Turio!Which of you saw Sir Eglamour of late?

translated_dialog: Sir Proteus! How's it going? And Turio, how are you? Which of you saw Sir Eglamour recently?
og_response: Not I.

translated_dialog: I didn't.
og_response: Nor I.

translated_dialog: Neither did I.
og_response: Saw you my daughter?

translated_dialog: Have you seen my daughter?
og_response: Neither.

translated_dialog: Not her either.
og_response: Why then,    She's fled unto that peasant Valentine;    And Eglamour is in her company.    'Tis true; for Friar Laurence met them both,    As he in penance wander'd through the forest;    Him he knew well, and guess'd that it was she,    But, being mask'd, he was not sure of it;    Besides, she did intend confession    At Patrick's cell this even; and there she was not;    These likelihoods confirm her flight from hence.    Therefore, I pray you, stand not to discourse,    But mount you presently and meet with me    Upon the rising of the mountain-foot    That leads towards Mantua, whither they are fled:    Dispatch, sweet gentlemen, and follow me.

translated_dialog: Well, then, she has run away to find that peasant Valentine, and Eglamour has accompanied her. It's true. Friar Lawrence has met them both as he wandered through the forest, repenting. He recognized Eglamour, and guessed that it was Silviabut since she was masked, he wasn't sure of it. Besides, she was planning on going to confession tonight at Patrick's place, but she wasn't there. All of these instances confirm that she has run away. Therefore, please, don't delay by talking. Get on horseback at once, and meet me by the base of the mountain that leads toward Mantua, where they are going. Hurry up, sweet gentlemen, and follow me.
og_response: Why, this it is to be a peevish girl,    That flies her fortune when it follows her.    I'll after, more to be revenged on Eglamour    Than for the love of reckless Silvia.

translated_dialog: Well, she's a foolish girl for fleeing from a good courtship when it follows her. I'll go after hernot so much because I love the uncaring Silvia, but more because I want to take revenge on Eglamour.
og_response: And I will follow, more for Silvia's loveThan hate of Eglamour that goes with her.

translated_dialog: And I'll followbecause I love Silvia more than I hate Eglamour, who accompanies her.
og_response: And I will follow, more to cross that loveThan hate for Silvia that is gone for love.

translated_dialog: Come, come and be patient. We have to bring you to our captain.
og_response: A thousand more mischances than this oneHave learn'd me how to brook this patiently.

translated_dialog: A thousand misfortunes greater than this one have taught me how to endure this patiently.
og_response: Come, bring her away.

translated_dialog: Come, bring her here.
og_response: Where is the gentleman that was with her?

translated_dialog: Where is the gentleman that was with her?
og_response: Being nimble-footed, he hath outrun us,    But Moyses and Valerius follow him.    Go thou with her to the west end of the wood;    There is our captain: we'll follow him that's fled;    The thicket is beset; he cannot 'scape.

translated_dialog: He moved quickly and lightly, so he outran us. But Moyses and Valerius are following him. Go with her to the west end of the forestthat's where our captain is. We'll follow the one who ran away. The bushes surround him; he can't escape.
og_response: Come, I must bring you to our captain's cave:Fear not; he bears an honourable mind,And will not use a woman lawlessly.

translated_dialog: Come, I must bring you to our captain's cave. Don't be afraid. He has an honorable mind, and won't mistreat a woman.
og_response: O Valentine, this I endure for thee!

translated_dialog: Increasing familiarity can make people feel more at home, no matter where they are! This shadowy deserted placea forest that no one ever visitsnow feels better to me than towns bustling with people. Here, I can sit alone, and no one sees me. I can tune the sad songs I sing to the nightingale's sorrowful notes. Oh, you that live in my breast: don't leave my love's dwelling place so long without a tenant. Otherwise, it will become a ruin, and the building will fall and leave no memory of what it was! Revive me with your presence, Silvia. You gentle, beautiful creature: treasure me, your abandoned lover! What's this shouting and what hustle do we have here today? These are my friends that make their desires into their laws. They are following some unfortunate traveler. They love me, but I have a lot to do to keep them from committing uncivil and shocking acts. Valentine, keep away for now. Who's coming here?
og_response: Madam, this service I have done for you,    Though you respect not aught your servant doth,    To hazard life and rescue you from him    That would have forced your honour and your love;    Vouchsafe me, for my meed, but one fair look;    A smaller boon than this I cannot beg    And less than this, I am sure, you cannot give.

translated_dialog: Madam, I have done you this service. But you don't value what Iyour servanthave done. I risked my life and rescued you from the outlaw that would have raped you. Give me just one beautiful look as my reward. I cannot ask for a smaller favor. And I am sure this is the least you can do for me.
og_response: [Aside]  How like a dream is this I see and hear!Love, lend me patience to forbear awhile.

translated_dialog: [To himself] What I see and hear is like a dream! Love, give me patience to wait for a while.
og_response: O miserable, unhappy that I am!

translated_dialog: Oh, I am miserable and unhappy!
og_response: Unhappy were you, madam, ere I came;But by my coming I have made you happy.

translated_dialog: You were unhappy before I came, madam. But my coming here has made you happy.
og_response: By thy approach thou makest me most unhappy.

translated_dialog: But your loving advances make me very unhappy.
og_response: [Aside]  And me, when he approacheth to your presence.

translated_dialog: [To herself] And when he makes those advances to you, Silvia, it makes me unhappy.
og_response: Had I been seized by a hungry lion,    I would have been a breakfast to the beast,    Rather than have false Proteus rescue me.    O, Heaven be judge how I love Valentine,    Whose life's as tender to me as my soul!    And full as much, for more there cannot be,    I do detest false perjured Proteus.    Therefore be gone; solicit me no more.

translated_dialog: If I were taken by a hungry lion, I would rather have been the beast's breakfast than have the false Proteus rescue me. Oh, Heaven may be the judge of how much I love Valentine, whose life's as precious to me as my soul! And I hate the false, lying Proteus the mostmore than words can express. Therefore, leave. Don't pursue me anymore.
og_response: What dangerous action, stood it next to death,    Would I not undergo for one calm look!    O, 'tis the curse in love, and still approved,    When women cannot love where they're beloved!

translated_dialog: I would take on any fighteven a deadly onejust for one loving glance! Oh, it's still proved true that love's curse is a woman who cannot reciprocate love.
og_response: When Proteus cannot love where he's beloved.    Read over Julia's heart, thy first best love,    For whose dear sake thou didst then rend thy faith    Into a thousand oaths; and all those oaths    Descended into perjury, to love me.    Thou hast no faith left now, unless thou'dst two;    And that's far worse than none;   better have none    Than plural faith which is too much by one:    Thou counterfeit to thy true friend!

translated_dialog: No, when Proteus can't reciprocate love. Study Julia's heart, your first and truest love.You tore up your fidelity to Julia into a thousand false promises (which are now just lies) in order to love me. You have no fidelity left nowunless you maintain two separate senses of loyalty, one to her and one to me. And that's worse than if you had none. It's better to be faithful to no one than to be faithful to two women. That's too much for either woman to bear. You are a false imitation of a true friend like Valentine!
og_response: In loveWho respects friend?

translated_dialog: Who takes a friend into consideration when it comes to love?
og_response: All men but Proteus.

translated_dialog: All men do, except Proteus.
og_response: Nay, if the gentle spirit of moving words    Can no way change you to a milder form,    I'll woo you like a soldier, at arms' end,    And love you 'gainst the nature of love,force ye.

translated_dialog: No, if the gentle nature of my wooing words cannot in any way make you behave more mildly, then I'll woo you like a soldier. I'll rape you at knife point, and love you in a way that goes against the nature of love.
og_response: O heaven!

translated_dialog: Oh God!
og_response: I'll force thee yield to my desire.

translated_dialog: I'll force you to give in to my desire.
og_response: Ruffian, let go that rude uncivil touch,Thou friend of an ill fashion!

translated_dialog: Rascal, stop that rude, brutish behavior, you wicked friend!
og_response: Valentine!

translated_dialog: Valentine!
og_response: Thou common friend, that's without faith or love,    For such is a friend now; treacherous man!    Thou hast beguiled my hopes; nought but mine eye    Could have persuaded me: now I dare not say    I have one friend alive; thou wouldst disprove me.    Who should be trusted, when one's own right hand    Is perjured to the bosom? Proteus,    I am sorry I must never trust thee more,    But count the world a stranger for thy sake.    The private wound is deepest: O time most accurst,    'Mongst all foes that a friend should be the worst!

translated_dialog: You are an ordinary friend that's without faith or love. And such a friend is now a treacherous man! You have deceived my hopes: nothing could have persuaded me about that except for witnessing your behavior firsthand. Now I won't dare to say that I have only one friend that's alivebecause you would prove me wrong. Who should be trusted, when one's closest friend is a liar? Proteus, I am sorry I must never trust you again, but consider you a stranger. The personal wound is the deepest one. Oh, what an awful moment! Its terrible when a friend should be the worst among your enemies.
og_response: My shame and guilt confounds me.    Forgive me, Valentine:   if hearty sorrow    Be a sufficient ransom for offence,    I tender 't here;   I do as truly suffer    As e'er I did commit.

translated_dialog: My shame and guilt overcome me. Forgive me, Valentine. If hearty sorrow can be enough to make up for my offense, I offer it here. I do suffer for the wrongs I've committed.
og_response: Then I am paid;    And once again I do receive thee honest.    Who by repentance is not satisfied    Is nor of heaven nor earth, for these are pleased.    By penitence the Eternal's wrath's appeased:    And, that my love may appear plain and free,    All that was mine in Silvia I give thee.

translated_dialog: Then I am satisfied. And once again, I'll regard you as an honest man. He who is not satisfied with someone else's repentance is not of heaven or of earth. For repentance pleases both people on earth, and also God. Repentance calms God's anger. And to prove that my friendship can be honest and generous, I give you my claim to Silvia.
og_response: O me unhappy!

translated_dialog: Oh, I am unhappy!
og_response: Look to the boy.

translated_dialog: Take care of that boy.
og_response: Why, boy! Why, wag! How now! What's the matter?Look up; speak.

translated_dialog: Boy! Come on, boy! What's the matter? Look up and speak.
og_response: O good sir, my master charged me to deliver a ringto Madam Silvia, which, out of my neglect, was never done.

translated_dialog: Oh, good sir. My master instructed me to deliver a ring to Madam Silvia, which I forgot to do.
og_response: Where is that ring, boy?

translated_dialog: Where is that ring, boy?
og_response: Here 'tis; this is it.

translated_dialog: Here it is.
og_response: How! Let me see:Why, this is the ring I gave to Julia.

translated_dialog: Let me see. But this is the ring I gave to Julia!
og_response: O, cry you mercy, sir, I have mistook:This is the ring you sent to Silvia.

translated_dialog: Oh, forgive me sir. I have made a mistake. This is the ring you sent to Silvia.
og_response: But how camest thou by this ring? At my departI gave this unto Julia.

translated_dialog: But how is it that you have this ring? I gave it to Julia when we said goodbye.
og_response: And Julia herself did give it me;And Julia herself hath brought it hither.

translated_dialog: And Julia herself gave it to me. And Julia herself has brought it here.
og_response: How! Julia!

translated_dialog: Julia?! Is that you?
og_response: Behold her that gave aim to all thy oaths,    And entertain'd 'em deeply in her heart.    How oft hast thou with perjury cleft the root!    O Proteus, let this habit make thee blush!    Be thou ashamed that I have took upon me    Such an immodest raiment, if shame live    In a disguise of love:    It is the lesser blot, modesty finds,    Women to change their shapes than men their minds.

translated_dialog: Look at me, the women who was once the object of all your promises. I received them deeply in my heart. How often have you split the bottom of my heart when you broke a promise! Oh, Proteus, let my outfit make you blush! Be ashamed that I have been wearing such immodest clothingif it can be shameful to wear a disguise for the sake of love. It's much more appropriate and a lesser fault for women to be deceptive in their appearance than for men to be deceptive in their love.
og_response: Than men their minds! 'Tis true.    O heaven! Were man    But constant, he were perfect.   That one error    Fills him with faults; makes him run through all the sins:    Inconstancy falls off ere it begins.    What is in Silvia's face, but I may spy    More fresh in Julia's with a constant eye?

translated_dialog: Than for men to be unfaithful! That's true. Oh heaven! If only man could be faithful, then he would be perfect. Because one mistake fills him with faults, he commits so many sins. Being unfaithful gets old very fast. What is in Silvia's face, that I can't see more clearly in Julia's with faithful eyes?
og_response: Come, come, a hand from either:    Let me be blest to make this happy close;    'Twere pity two such friends should be long foes.

translated_dialog: Come, come, give me your hands. Let me be blessed to make a happy end to this. It would be a pity if two friends like you should be enemies.
og_response: Bear witness, Heaven, I have my wish for ever.

translated_dialog: Heaven, be my witness. I will keep my wish forever.
og_response: And I mine.

translated_dialog: And I will keep mine.
og_response: A prize, a prize, a prize!

translated_dialog: A prize, a prize, a prize!
og_response: Forbear, forbear, I say! It is my lord the duke.Your grace is welcome to a man disgraced,Banished Valentine.

translated_dialog: Stop, stop, I say! It is my lord, the Duke. It is I, a dishonored manthe banished Valentinewho welcomes Your Grace.
og_response: Sir Valentine!

translated_dialog: Sir Valentine!
og_response: Yonder is Silvia; and Silvia's mine.

translated_dialog: There's Silvia, and Silvia is mine.
og_response: Turio, give back, or else embrace thy death;    Come not within the measure of my wrath;    Do not name Silvia thine; if once again,    Verona shall not hold thee.   Here she stands;    Take but possession of her with a touch:    I dare thee but to breathe upon my love.

translated_dialog: Turio, move back, or else accept your death. Don't come close to the range of my anger. Do not call Silvia yours. If you do that once more, Verona won't protect you. Here she is. Go ahead, try to only touch her and take her as your own; I dare you to do so much as breathe on my love.
og_response: Sir Valentine, I care not for her, I;    I hold him but a fool that will endanger    His body for a girl that loves him not:    I claim her not, and therefore she is thine.

translated_dialog: Sir Valentine, I don't care about her. I think a man would be foolish to put his body in danger for a girl that doesn't love him. I don't call her mine, and therefore she is yours.
og_response: The more degenerate and base art thou,    To make such means for her as thou hast done    And leave her on such slight conditions.    Now, by the honour of my ancestry,    I do applaud thy spirit, Valentine,    And think thee worthy of an empress' love:    Know then, I here forget all former griefs,    Cancel all grudge, repeal thee home again,    Plead a new state in thy unrivall'd merit,    To which I thus subscribe:   Sir Valentine,    Thou art a gentleman and well derived;    Take thou thy Silvia, for thou hast deserved her.

translated_dialog: [To TURIO] You are all the more degenerate and lowly, because you went to such lengths to win her, and then just left her based on such insubstantial grounds. [To VALENTINE] Now, by the honor of my ancestry, I congratulate your spirit, Valentine. And I think you are worthy of an empress' love. Know that I will now forget all previous trouble, cancel all hatred, and allow you to return to your home again. Ask for a new set of circumstances based on your unquestionable merit, and I'll agree to them.Sir Valentine, you are a gentleman. Take Silvia, because you have earned her.
og_response: I thank your grace; the gift hath made me happy.    I now beseech you, for your daughter's sake,    To grant one boom that I shall ask of you.

translated_dialog: Thank you, your Grace. The gift has made me happy. I now ask youfor your daughter's saketo do me one more favor.
og_response: I grant it, for thine own, whate'er it be.

translated_dialog: I'll grant your request, whatever it may be.
og_response: These banish'd men that I have kept withal    Are men endued with worthy qualities:    Forgive them what they have committed here    And let them be recall'd from their exile:    They are reformed, civil, full of good    And fit for great employment, worthy lord.

translated_dialog: These banished men that I have lived with have some valuable qualities. Forgive them for what they have done here, and let them return home from their exile. They are reformed, civil, full of goodness, and ready to do you great service, noble Lord.
og_response: Thou hast prevail'd; I pardon them and thee:    Dispose of them as thou know'st their deserts.    Come, let us go: we will include all jars    With triumphs, mirth and rare solemnity.

translated_dialog: You have convinced me. I pardon them, and I pardon you. Make arrangements for them in accordance with what they deserve. Come, let's go. We will bring this all to an end with festivities, joy, and a marvelous celebration.
og_response: And, as we walk along, I dare be boldWith our discourse to make your grace to smile.What think you of this page, my lord?

translated_dialog: And as we walk along, I will dare to be bold with our conversationso I can make your Grace smile. [Referring to JULIA] What do you think of this boy, my lord?
og_response: I think the boy hath grace in him; he blushes.

translated_dialog: I think the boy is charming. He blushes.
og_response: I warrant you, my lord, more grace than boy.

translated_dialog: I guarantee, my lord, that this person is more beautiful and charming than this person is a boy.
og_response: What mean you by that saying?

translated_dialog: What do you mean by that?
og_response: Please you, I'll tell you as we pass along,    That you will wonder what hath fortuned.    Come, Proteus; 'tis your penance but to hear    The story of your loves discovered:    That done, our day of marriage shall be yours;    One feast, one house, one mutual happiness.
